Name: In both plosives and fricatives
Description: Voicing contrast in both plosives and fricatives

Name: None missing in /p t k b d g/
Laterals, but no /l/, no obstruent laterals

Name: no nasal vs. oral vowel contrast
Description: no nasal vs. oral vowel contrast

Description: two-way nasal vs. oral vowel contrast (/ṽ/ vs. /V/) without nasal spreading

Description: two-way nasal vs. oral vowel contrast (/ṽ/ vs. /V/) with nasal spreading

Description: four-way nasal vs. oral vowel contrast (/ṽ/ vs. /ṽː/ vs. /V/ vs. /Vː/) without nasal spreading

Description: four-way nasal vs. oral vowel contrast (/ṽ/ vs. /ṽː/ vs. /V/ v /Vː/) with nasal spreading

Name: Initial
Description: Initial: stress is on the first syllable

Name: Second
Description: Second: stress is on the second syllable

Name: Third
Description: Third: stress is on the third syllable

Name: Antepenultimate
Description: Antepenultimate: stress is on the antepenultimate (third from the right) syllable

Name: Penultimate
Description: Penultimate: stress is on the penultimate (second from the right) syllable

Name: Ultimate
Description: Ultimate: stress is on the ultimate (last) syllable

Name: Left-edge: First or second
Description: Left-edge: Stress is on the first or second syllable

Name: Left-oriented: One of the first three
Description: Left-oriented: The third syllable is involved

Name: Right-edge: Ultimate or penultimate
Description: Right-edge: Stress on ultimate or penultimate syllable

Name: Right-oriented: One of the last three
Unbounded: Stress can be anywhere
Description: Unbounded: Stress can be anywhere in the word

Name: No weight
Description: No weight, or weight factor unknown

Name: Long vowel
Description: Long vowel: long vowels are heavy for stress

Name: Coda consonant
Description: Coda consonant: closed syllables are heavy for stress

Name: Long vowel or coda consonant
Description: Long vowel + Coda: long vowels or closed syllables

Name: Prominence
Description: Prominence: other factors are heavy for stress

Name: Combined
Description: Combined: two of the above factors determine weight

Name: Trochaic
Description: Trochaic: left-hand syllable in the foot is strong

Name: Iambic
Description: Iambic: right-hand syllable in the foot is strong

Name: Dual: both trochaic and iambic
Description: Dual: system has both trochaic and iambic feet

Name: Equal prefixing and suffixing
Description: Approximately equal amounts of suffixing and prefixing

Name: No case marking
Description: Inflectional case marking is absent or minimal

Name: Core cases only
Description: Inflectional case marking is syncretic for core cases only

Name: Core and non-core
Description: Inflectional case marking is syncretic for core and non-core cases

Name: No syncretism
Description: Inflectional case marking is never syncretic

Name: Not syncretic
Description: Subject person/number marking is never syncretic

Name: Plural complete reduplication
Description: Plural by complete reduplication of stem

Name: Mixed morphological plural
Description: Morphological plural with no method primary

Name: Only human nouns, optional
Description: Plural only in human nouns, optional

Name: Only human nouns, obligatory
Description: Plural only in human nouns, obligatory

Name: All nouns, always optional
Description: Plural in all nouns, always optional

Name: All nouns, optional in inanimates
Description: Plural in all nouns, optional in inanimates

Name: All nouns, always obligatory
Description: Plural in all nouns, always obligatory

Name: Person-number stem + pronominal plural affix
Description: Person-number stem with a pronominal plural affix

Name: Person-number stem + nominal plural affix
Description: Person-number stem with a nominal plural affix

Name: Person stem + pronominal plural affix
Description: Person stem with a pronominal plural affix

Name: Person stem + nominal plural affix
Description: Person stem with a nominal plural affix

Name: Associative same as additive plural
Description: Associative plural marker also used for additive plurals

Name: Demonstrative word used as definite article
Description: Demonstrative word used as marker of definiteness

Name: No definite, but indefinite article
Description: No definite article but indefinite article

Name: Indefinite word distinct from 'one'
Description: Indefinite word distinct from numeral for 'one'

Name: Indefinite word same as 'one'
Description: Numeral for 'one' is used as indefinite article

Name: No indefinite, but definite article
Description: No indefinite article but definite article

Name: Unrelated
Description: Third person pronouns and demonstratives are unrelated to demonstratives

Name: Related for all demonstratives
Description: Third person pronouns and demonstratives are related to all demonstratives

Name: Related to remote demonstratives
Description: Third person pronouns and demonstratives are related to remote demonstratives

Name: Related to non-remote demonstratives
Description: Third person pronouns and demonstratives are related to non-remote demonstratives

Name: Related by gender markers
Description: Third person pronouns and demonstratives are related by gender markers

Name: Related for non-human reference
Description: Third person pronouns and demonstratives are related for non-human reference

Name: In 3rd person + 1st and/or 2nd person
Description: Gender distinctions in 3rd person plus 1st and/or 2nd person

Name: 3rd person only, but also non-singular
Description: Gender distinctions in 3rd person only, but in both singular and non-singular

Name: 3rd person singular only
Description: Gender distinctions in 3rd person singular only

Name: 1st or 2nd person but not 3rd
Description: Gender distinctions in 1st or 2nd person but not 3rd

Name: 3rd person non-singular only
Description: Gender distinctions in 3rd person non-singular only

Name: No politeness distinction
Description: Second person pronouns encode no politeness distinction

Name: Binary politeness distinction
Description: Second person pronouns encode a binary politeness distinction

Name: Multiple politeness distinctions
Description: Second person pronouns encode multiple politeness distinctions

Name: Pronouns avoided for politeness
Description: Second person pronouns are dominantly avoided for politeness reasons

Name: Identical
Description: Intensifiers and reflexive pronouns are formally identical

Name: Differentiated
Description: Intensifiers and reflexive pronouns are formally differentiated

Name: Pronouns and nouns
Description: Person marking for pronouns and nouns

Name: Case stem change
Description: Case coded by changes within noun stem

Name: Mixed morphological case
Description: Mixed morphological case strategies with none primary

Name: No case affixes or adpositional clitics
Description: Neither case affixes nor adpositional clitics

Name: None
Description: Zero: Ordinal numerals do not exist

Name: One, two, three
Description: One: No distinction of cardinal and ordinal numerals

Name: First, two, three
Description: First: Cardinal and ordinal numerals are identical except for 'one' and 'first'

Name: One-th, two-th, three-th
Description: One-th: One-th: Ordinal numerals are derived from cardinal numerals

Name: First/one-th, two-th, three-th
Description: First/One-th: All ordinal numerals are derived from cardinal numerals with different allomorphs for 'first' one of which is morphologically independent of 'one'

Name: First, two-th, three-th
Description: Two-th: Two-th: Ordinal numerals from 'two' upwards are derived from cardinal numerals, 'first' is suppletive

Name: First, second, three-th
Description: Second: 'First' and a small set of consecutive higher ordinal numerals are suppletive

Name: Marked by mixed or other strategies
Description: Marked by mixed or other strategies

Name: Formally similar, without interrogative
Description: Formally similar, not involving interrogative expression

Name: Prefixes and suffixes
Description: Both possessive prefixes and possessive suffixes, with neither primary

Name: Genitives and adjectives collapsed
Description: Moderately differentiated, with genitives and adjectives collapsed

Name: Genitives and relative clauses collapsed
Description: Moderately differentiated, with genitives and relative clauses collapsed

Name: Adjectives and relative clauses collapsed
Description: Moderately differentiated, with adjectives and relative clauses collapsed

Name: Not without noun
Description: Adjective may not occur without noun

Name: Without marking
Description: Adjective may occur without noun, and without marking

Name: Marked by prefix
Description: Adjective may occur without noun, obligatorily marked by prefix

Name: Marked by suffix
Description: Adjective may occur without noun, obligatorily marked by suffix

Name: Marked by preceding word
Description: Adjective may occur without noun, obligatorily marked by preceding word

Name: Marked by following word
Description: Adjective may occur without noun, obligatorily marked by following word

Name: Marked by mixed or other strategies
Description: Adjective may occur without noun, obligatorily marked by mixed or other strategies

Name: Sentential
Description: Sentential: dependent-marking of the finite clause is retained for S, A and P

Name: Possessive-Accusative
Description: Possessive-Accusative: S/A treated as possessors, P retains sentential marking

Name: Ergative-Possessive
Description: Ergative-Possessive: S/P treated as possessors, A treated differently

Name: Double-Possessive
Description: Double-Possessive: All major arguments treated as possessors

Name: Mixed
Description: Mixed: Several patterns in the same language

Name: Restricted
Description: Not both A and P in the same construction

Name: Identity
Description: Nominal and verbal conjunction are largely identical

Name: Differentiation
Description: Nominal and verbal conjunction are different

Name: Both expressed by juxtaposition
Description: Nominal and verbal conjunction are primarily expressed by juxtaposition

Name: No grammatical marking
Description: No grammatical marking of perfective/imperfective distinction

Name: Present, no remoteness distinctions
Description: Past/non-past distinction marked; no remoteness distinction

Name: Present, 2-3 remoteness distinctions
Description: Past/non-past distinction marked; 2-3 degrees of remoteness distinguished

Name: Present, 4 or more remoteness distinctions
Description: Past/non-past distinction marked; at least 4 degrees of remoteness distinguished

Name: No past tense
Description: No grammatical marking of past/non-past distinction

Name: No inflectional future
Description: No inflectional marking of future/non-future distinction

Name: From possessive
Description: Perfect of the 'have'-type (derived from a possessive construction)

Name: From 'finish', 'already'
Description: Perfect derived from word meaning 'finish' or 'already'

Name: Mixed type
Description: Combination of tense-aspect strategies with none primary

Name: Second singular and second plural
Description: The language has morphologically dedicated second singular as well as second plural imperatives

Name: Second singular
Description: The language has morphologically dedicated second singular imperatives but no morphologically dedicated second plural imperatives

Name: Second plural
Description: The language has morphologically dedicated second plural imperatives but no morphologically dedicated second singular imperatives

Name: Second person number-neutral
Description: The language has morphologically dedicated second person imperatives that do not distinguish between singular and plural

Name: No second-person imperatives
Description: The language has no morphologically dedicated second-person imperatives at all

Name: Normal imperative + normal negative
Description: The prohibitive uses the verbal construction of the second singular imperative and a sentential negative strategy found in (indicative) declaratives

Name: Normal imperative + special negative
Description: The prohbitive uses the verbal construction of the second singular imperative and a sentential negative strategy not found in (indicative) declaratives

Name: Special imperative + normal negative
Description: The prohibitive uses a verbal construction other than the second singular imperative and a sentential negative strategy found in (indicative) declaratives

Name: Special imperative + special negative
Description: The prohibitive uses a verbal construction other than the second singular imperative and a sentential negative strategy not found in (indicative) declaratives

Name: Maximal system
Description: The language has a maximal system, but not a minimal one

Name: Minimal system
Description: The language has a minimal system, but not a maximal one

Name: Both types of system
Description: The language has both a maximal and a minimal system

Name: Neither type of system
Description: The language has neither a maximal nor a minimal system

Name: Affixes on verbs
Description: The language can express situational possibility with affixes on verbs

Name: Verbal constructions
Description: The language cannot express situational possibility with affixes on verbs, but with verbal constructions

Name: Other kinds of markers
Description: The language cannot express situational possibility with affixes on verbs or with verbal constructions, but with other kinds of markers

Name: Verbal constructions
Description: The language can express epistemic possibility with verbal constructions

Name: Affixes on verbs
Description: The language cannot express epistemic possibility with verbal constructions, but with affixes on verbs

Name: Other
Description: The language cannot express epistemic possibility with verbal constructions or with affixes on verbs, but with other kinds of markers

Name: Overlap for both possibility and necessity
Description: The language has markers that can code both situational and epistemic modality, both for possibility and necessity

Name: Overlap for either possibility or necessity
Description: The language has markers that can code both situational and epistemic modality, but only for possibility or for necessity

Name: No overlap
Description: The language has no markers that can code both situational and epistemic modality

Name: Tense and aspect
Description: Suppletion in both tense and aspect

Name: None
Description: No suppletion in tense or aspect

Name: A regular and a suppletive form alternate
Description: A regular and a suppletive form alternate

Name: None (= no suppletive imperatives reported in the reference material)
Description: None (= no suppletive imperatives reported in the reference material)

Name: No dominant order
Description: Both orders with neither order dominant

Name: No dominant order
Description: Both orders with neither order dominant

Name: No dominant order
Description: More than one order with none dominant

Name: No dominant order
Description: More than one adposition type with none dominant

Name: No dominant order
Description: Both orders occur with neither order dominant

Name: No dominant order
Description: Both orders of noun and modifying adjective occur, with neither dominant

Name: Only internally-headed relative clauses
Description: Adjectives do not modify nouns, occurring as predicates in internally headed relative clauses

Name: Demonstrative before and after Noun
Description: Demonstrative simultaneously before and after noun

Name: Mixed
Description: Two or more of above types with none dominant

Name: No dominant order
Description: Both orders of numeral and noun with neither order dominant

Name: Mixed
Description: Mixed types of relative clause with none dominant

Name: No dominant order
Description: Both orders occur with neither order dominant

Name: Initial
Description: Question particle at beginning of sentence

Name: Final
Description: Question particle at end of sentence

Name: Second position
Description: Question particle in second position in sentence

Name: In either of two positions
Description: Question particle in either of two positions

Name: Mixed
Description: Mixed, some interrogative phrases obligatorily initial, some not

Name: Initial subordinator word
Description: Adverbial subordinators which are separate words and which appear at the beginning of the subordinate clause

Name: Final subordinator word
Description: Adverbial subordinators which are separate words and which appear at the end of the subordinate clause

Name: Mixed
Description: More than one type of adverbial subordinators with none dominant

Name: Other
Description: Languages not falling into one of the preceding four types

Name: Other
Description: Languages not falling into one of the preceding four types

Name: Other
Description: Languages not falling into one of the preceding four types

Name: Obligatory pronouns in subject position

Name: Subject affixes on verb
Description: Pronominal subjects are expressed by affixes on verbs

Description: Pronominal subjects are expressed by subject pronouns that occur in a different syntactic position from full noun phrase subjects

Description: Pronominal subjects are expressed only by pronouns in subject position, but these pronouns are often left out

Name: Mixed
Description: More than one of the above types with none dominant

Name: No person marking
Description: No person marking of any argument

Name: Only the A argument
Description: Person marking of only the A argument

Description: Person marking of only the P argument

Description: Person marking of the A or P argument

Description: Person marking of both the A and P arguments

Name: No person marking
Description: No person marking of the S

Description: No zero realization of third person S forms

Description: Zero realization of some third person singular forms

Description: Zero realization of all third person singular S forms

Description: Zero realization of all third person forms/No third person S forms

Description: Zero realization only of third person non-singular

Name: A and P do not or do not both occur on the verb
Description: A and P do not or do not both occur on the verb

Name: Both orders of A and P occur
Description: Both orders of A and P occur

Name: No reciprocals
Description: There are no non-iconic reciprocal constructions.

Name: Distinct from reflexive
Description: All reciprocal constructions are formally distinct from reflexive constructions.

Name: Mixed
Description: There are both reflexive and non-reflexive reciprocal constructions.

Name: Identical to reflexive
Description: The reciprocal and reflexive constructions are formally identical.

Description: Antipassive with patient-like argument left implicit

Name: Oblique patient
Description: Antipassive with patient-like argument expressed as oblique complement

Description: Benefactive object only; transitive base only

Description: Benefactive and other; transitive base only

Description: Non-benefactive object only; transitive base only

Description: Non-benefactive object only; intransitive base only

Description: Sequential type but no purposive type

Description: Purposive type but no sequential type

Name: Both
Description: Both sequential type and purposive type

Name: Neither
Description: No morphological type or compound type

Description: Morphological type but no compound type

Description: Compound type but no morphological type

Name: Both
Description: Both morphological type and compound type

Description: Negative word, unclear if verb or particle

Description: Variation between negative word and affix

Description: Symmetric and asymmetric standard negation: Type SymAsy

Name: Different
Description: Split (i.e. different) encoding of nominal and locational predication

Description: Shared (i.e. identical) encoding of nominal and locational predication

Description: The complement subject is left implicit

Between 4 and 5, 5, or between 5 and 6 categories

Name: None
Description: Green and blue not both encoded in any basic color term

Description: Red and yellow not both encoded in any basic color term

Description: No m in second person singular

Name: No preverbal neg
Description: Verb-initial but preverbal negative does not occur

Name: Word&OnlyWithAnotherNeg
Description: Separate word, immediately following verb, only occurs with another negative morpheme

Name: Suffix&OptDoubleNeg
Description: Suffix, optional double negation, can occur without a second negative

Name: Suffix&OnlyWithAnotherNeg
Description: Suffix, only occurs with another negative morpheme

Name: WordBetweenSAndO
Description: Separate word, between subject and object

Name: None
Description: Verb-initial but immediately postverbal negative or negative between subject and object does not occur

Name: OptDoubleNeg
Description: Separate word, optional double negation, with clause-final negative word possible without a second negative

Name: OnlyWithAnotherNeg
Description: Separate word, only occurs with another negative morpheme

Name: No clause-final neg
Description: Verb-initial but clause-final negative does not occur
